This code takes the raw-ish files available here:  

https://d396qusza40orc.cloudfront.net/getdata%2Fprojectfiles%2FUCI%20HAR%20Dataset.zip
  

The original authors have already provided a read-me describing these data (inside the above zip file), but I made some additions to help whoever might look at this data again:

These data were provided by: 

Jorge L. Reyes-Ortiz, Davide Anguita, Alessandro Ghio, Luca Oneto.
Smartlab - Non Linear Complex Systems Laboratory
DITEN - Universit√† degli Studi di Genova.
Via Opera Pia 11A, I-16145, Genoa, Italy.
activityrecognition@smartlab.ws
www.smartlab.ws

The data were also used in this publication:

Davide Anguita, Alessandro Ghio, Luca Oneto, Xavier Parra and Jorge L. Reyes-Ortiz. Human Activity Recognition on Smartphones using a Multiclass Hardware-Friendly Support Vector Machine. International Workshop of Ambient Assisted Living (IWAAL 2012). Vitoria-Gasteiz, Spain. Dec 2012

# So each participant in the study have provided their data, but it took way too long to figure out what was what. Below is the description provided by the authors (with my annotations marked with # )

For each record it is provided:
======================================

- Triaxial acceleration from the accelerometer (total acceleration) and the estimated body acceleration. # These data are in the 'Inertial Signals' folder, which you can ignore
- Triaxial Angular velocity from the gyroscope. # These data are in the 'Inertial Signals' folder, which you can ignore

## The next sets are the data you want. Each row across the various files is attached to a particular subject and a particular activity.

- A 561-feature vector with time and frequency domain variables. # for both of the test and train data sets. These are 'X_test.txt' and 'X_train.txt', respectively. These data are 'normalized', but also bounded within -1 to 1.
- Its activity label. ### these are the names of the types of activities done by each participant for a given set of data (walking, etc). 
- An identifier of the subject who carried out the experiment. ## these uniquely identify which data are associated with which participant: 'subject_train.txt' and 'subject_test.txt'

## the summary variable data generated by the researchers are the data in the 'X_train.txt' and 'X_test.txt' files. The names of these summary variables are available in:
## 'features.txt'


### the description of the 'features' (i also call them summary variables) is shown next. The original authors provide a description of these features in the 'features_info.txt' file.

### the 561 original feature names were altered slightly in the code (I removed all the 'ugly' charcaters (brackets, hashes, commas) from the the 'features.txt' file) resulting in these variable names:
